title: When you can't trust anything, you can't trust yourself
teaser: The deeper cost: constant distrust corrodes your ability to know anything at all.
framework: Matthew 6:33 - Seek first the kingdom... and all these things will be added

panels.heading: THE PARANOIA SPIRAL
panels.content:
You've trained yourself to distrust everything.

Every video could be a deepfake. Every statistic could be manipulated. Every news story could be propaganda. Every image could be AI-generated.

You fact-check compulsively. Question reflexively. Doubt automatically.

But here's what's happening beneath the surface:

**You're not just distrusting information. You're distrusting your own ability to discern.**

You second-guess your judgments. You spiral into research rabbit holes. You feel paralyzed because you can't be certain of anything.

The misinformation epidemic isn't just poisoning the information stream. It's poisoning your confidence in your own mind.

panels.heading: THE COST OF HYPERVIGILANCE
panels.content:
This constant vigilance is exhausting you.

You spend hours verifying a single claim. You cross-reference sources. You check the credibility of the fact-checkers. You analyze the bias of the analysts.

And even after all that work, you're still not sure.

Because the goalpost keeps moving. Just when you think you've found a reliable source, someone reveals its funding ties or hidden agenda.

You're running a race with no finish line.

And the cost is this: **You're so busy trying to find truth that you've lost the ability to rest in it.**

panels.heading: WHEN NOTHING FEELS REAL
panels.content:
The deepest cost of the misinformation crisis isn't what you believe. It's that **you can't fully believe anything anymore.**

73% of people say they encounter misinformation daily. But it's worse than that. The constant exposure to deception has made you numb.

You watch a video and think, "That's probably fake." You read a headline and think, "Someone's manipulating me." You see a photo and think, "AI could have made that."

Nothing feels solid. Nothing feels certain. Nothing feels real.

You're living in a fog of doubt. And it's seeping into everything—your relationships, your beliefs, your sense of reality itself.

This is the cost of a world without truth. **You stop knowing how to know.**

illustration.description: Dithered image of person surrounded by fractured mirrors or reality glitching/pixelating

panels.heading: A DIFFERENT KIND OF KNOWING
panels.content:
There's an ancient story about a different kind of knowing.

A teacher—the same one who claimed to be truth—was talking with his students. They were confused, anxious, uncertain about the future.

He said something that must have sounded absurd:

**"Do not let your hearts be troubled. Trust in God; trust also in me."**

Wait. Trust? In a world of deception and betrayal? How?

Because he was offering a different foundation.

Not more information. Not better fact-checking. Not a foolproof system.

A relationship. With someone who doesn't shift, doesn't deceive, doesn't manipulate.

Someone you can actually trust.

panels.heading: THE EXHAUSTION OF ENDLESS VERIFICATION
panels.content:
You're exhausted because you're trying to verify everything on your own.

Every fact. Every claim. Every piece of information. You're the sole arbiter of truth in your life, and the weight is crushing you.

But what if truth isn't something you achieve through endless research?

What if it's someone you encounter?

Jesus didn't say, "I have the truth." He said, **"I am the truth."**

Not a dataset you download. Not a narrative you verify. A person you know.

And knowing a person is different from knowing facts.

It's trust. It's relationship. It's rest.

Maybe that's what you've been missing.

panels.heading: THE INVITATION
panels.content:
God,

I'm exhausted from trying to verify everything. I don't trust anything anymore—not the news, not the sources, not even my own judgment.

I'm drowning in information and starving for something solid.

If truth is more than facts—if it's a person I can know and trust—then introduce me.

Because I'm tired of the fog. I need something real.

Amen.
